examples.en: There is some sort of unwritten rule that says people are only allowed to speak Japanese in this school.
examples.ja: 学校では日本語でしか話してはいけないという不文律のようなものがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: This <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> <kanji>law</kanji> is a law that hasn't been written down. It's an <vocabulary>unwritten law</vocabulary>, like taking your shoes off and showering every day.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We shouldn’t allow our bloodline to die out.
examples.ja: 我々の血脈を絶やさせるべきではない。

examples.en: We must continue to preserve our family's bloodline in the future.
examples.ja: これからも、一族の血脈をしっかり保っていかなければならない。

examples.en: We received information that a woman who bears this bloodline is somewhere in Tokyo.
examples.ja: この血脈を引く女性が東京のどこかにいるという情報が入った。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Blood</kanji> flows through your <kanji>vein</kanji>s, carrying the stories of your <vocabulary>lineage</vocabulary>, your <vocabulary>bloodline</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is quite formal and literary.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Nemo and his family are fish called clownfish.
examples.ja: ニモやその家族は、隠熊之実という魚だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: I want you to try to <kanji>bear</kanji> <kanji>this</kanji> <kanji>truth</kanji> and that's these kanji make up the word <vocabulary>clownfish</vocabulary>! Do you think a clownfish is this bear? I'm telling the truth! Maybe.
reading_mnemonic:
This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for all the kanji. You haven't learned these readings for 之 or 実 yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you get too close to a <vocabulary>clownfish</vocabulary>, it will hide inside its stinging anemone and shout, "YOU DON'T <reading>KNOW ME</reading> (のみ)! It's true, you don't know this clownfish, but you want to. I guess all of them are afraid of strangers though... how will you know me if you don't give me a chance, clownfish?!

examples.en: Hey, thanks for the report.
examples.ja: どーも、報告乙です。

examples.en: We agree with the contract as outlined below with regards to the subcontract of the first company, Tofugu, and the second company, WaniKani.
examples.ja: 合同会社トーフグを甲とし、ワニカニを乙として、甲の業務の委託に関して、次の通り契約を締結する。

examples.en: It’s very neat to look over my hometown from the top of the mountain.
examples.ja: こうして山頂から生まれ故郷を見渡すのも、また乙なものですねぇ。

meaning_mnemonic:
If something is the <kanji>latter</kanji>, it can't be first, it has to be at least <vocabulary>second</vocabulary>. This works for lists too. So if you have A through D, it's going to be <vocabulary>B</vocabulary>.

This word is also used as slang for おつかれさま, which is where the <vocabulary>thanks</vocabulary> meaning comes from. It can also be used as a prefix to mean <vocabulary>chic</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: It’s hard to say which result is better.
examples.ja: どちらも甲乙つけがたい出来栄えだ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>A</kanji> and <kanji>B</kanji> make <vocabulary>A and B</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Periodic thinning of forests makes the rest of trees grow thick trunks and tough, healthy branches and leaves.
examples.ja: 間伐を行うことで、残った木は幹が太く枝葉がしっかりとした健全な木に育ちます。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Fell</kanji> trees in <kanji>interval</kanji>s, instead of all at once, and it's called <vocabulary>tree thinning</vocabulary>. That way there's still some forest there, but you get your wood to use for other things too.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Notification is necessary before felling a forest.
examples.ja: 森林を伐採する際は、事前に届け出が必要です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Fell</kanji> trees and <kanji>gather</kanji> them up. That's called <vocabulary>lumbering</vocabulary>. Or if you cut them all down and take every last one, it's <vocabulary>deforestation</vocabulary> and you should be ashamed!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A thirty percent salary cut was announced by the company.
examples.ja: 会社から、三割の減俸を言い渡されました。

meaning_mnemonic: Your boss says she's going to <kanji>decrease</kanji> your <kanji>salary</kanji> with a company-wide <vocabulary>salary reduction</vocabulary>. You should probably start looking for a new job that won't do <vocabulary>salary cut</vocabulary>s like this.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

examples.en: This player was offered an extraordinary annual salary, but he rejected it and stayed with his team.
examples.ja: この選手は、破格の年俸をオファーされましたが、それを蹴ってチームに留まりました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>salary</kanji> you get each <kanji>year</kanji> is an <vocabulary>annual salary</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

examples.en: While working at the newspaper office, I've been attending night classes.
examples.ja: 新聞局で働く傍ら、夜間学校に通っています。

examples.en: Alongside the housework, she also runs an online shop.
examples.ja: 彼女は家事の傍ら、オンラインショップも運営している。

examples.en: The puppy, as if seeking the warmth of its mother, curled up beside her and quietly drifted into the world of dreams.
examples.ja: 子犬は、母犬のぬくもりを確かめるように、その傍らで小さく丸まり、静かに夢の世界へと落ちていった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji 傍 literally means nearby or side, but here in 傍ら it's being used figuratively, which is why this means while or alongside. 傍ら can mean beside in a physical sense, but you'll more often see it in writing to show someone doing two things at once, like 仕事の傍ら勉強している (studying while working). Basically, it's like you're doing another task or activity beside your main one.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You do your job <vocabulary>while</vocabulary> thinking about the <reading>cutter war</reading> (かたわ) — a never-ending war to cut budgets at work. Imagine all the colleagues you've already lost to the cutter war layoffs… You never know whether you've survived the latest round of cuts either, so you gotta work while worrying about these corporate bloodbaths. Yeesh!

examples.en: At our company we use special techniques to cheaply do resin relief printing and direct plate making.
examples.ja: 我が社では、特殊な技術を用いて、樹脂凸版の直接製版を格安で行っています。

meaning_mnemonic: Press <kanji>uneven</kanji> carvings into paper to make the newest <kanji>edition</kanji> of your magazine. What you're using is a <vocabulary>letterpress</vocabulary>. This made mass printing nice and cheap(ish) in Japan!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because はん becomes ぱん here.

examples.en: It has distinctly uneven features, doesn’t it?
examples.ja: 凹凸のはっきりした顔立ちですね。

meaning_mnemonic: A surface covered in <kanji>convex</kanji> and <kanji>concave</kanji> parts is going to be really <vocabulary>uneven</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rough</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The yakuza is using my adultery to blackmail me.
examples.ja: 不倫をダシにヤクザに恐喝されています。

meaning_mnemonic: A man in a leather jacket <kanji>scold</kanji>s you and is using <kanji>fear</kanji> tactics to get paid. He's <vocabulary>blackmailing</vocabulary> you! That's illegal. Come to think of it, he's probably a member of the yakuza. You should move.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How many tsubo is this land?
examples.ja: この土地は何坪ぐらいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: My brother nearly drowns in women and alcohol, and is buried in his totally corrupted life.
examples.ja: 兄は酒と女に溺れ、完全に堕落した生活を送っています。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>degradation</kanji> <kanji>fall</kanji> is a fall into <vocabulary>depravity</vocabulary>. Meaning you'll probably lead a life of <vocabulary>degradation</vocabulary>. Stealing, stabbing, money laundering, various excesses… That kind of depravity.

堕落 refers to a state of falling into a bad or immoral condition, whether it's about a person's character or a society and its values.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Tadasuke Ooka was promoted to magistrate at a young age.
examples.ja: 大岡忠相は、若くして江戸町奉行に昇進した。

examples.en: Can you take this compass to the shogunate administrator's office over there?
examples.ja: この羅針盤をあそこの奉行所に届けてくれないか？

examples.en: When we have nabe, my boyfriend always takes charge of the nabe, so it's easy for me.
examples.ja: 鍋の時はいつも彼氏が鍋奉行してくれるんで、楽なんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you can <kanji>dedicate</kanji> yourself to <kanji>go</kanji>ing to a bunch of meetings and dealing with everyone's problems you'll make a good <vocabulary>magistrate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned either of these readings yet. Sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you:

The <vocabulary>magistrate</vocabulary> is the only person who's allowed to drink <reading>boo</reading>ze and eat <reading>gyo</reading>za (ぶぎょう). If you see someone simultaneously drinking booze and eating dumplings in Japan, you'll know that person is the magistrate!

examples.en: We’ll cross the channel in this ferry.
examples.ja: このフェリーで海峡を渡ります。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>ravine</kanji> in the water connecting two <kanji>sea</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>channel</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>strait</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Have you ever crossed the bridge that spans over this ravine?
examples.ja: この峡谷に架かる吊橋を渡ったことはありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>ravine</kanji> in a <kanji>valley</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>ravine</vocabulary>. It can also be a <vocabulary>gorge</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>canyon</vocabulary>. They're usually really big. Like the Grand Canyon!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 谷 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you're going to travel through a huge <vocabulary>ravine</vocabulary> you have to stay hydrated. The best thing to bring is some taste, cold <reading>Coke</reading> (こく). Nothing quenches your thirst from sweating through a long, rough ravine like delicious Coke!

examples.en: I sent flowers to express my condolences.
examples.ja: 弔意を表して花を贈りました。

meaning_mnemonic: Express your unique <kanji>idea</kanji> of <kanji>condolence</kanji> by offering your <vocabulary>condolence</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>sympathy</vocabulary> to people who are going through hard times.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Who will read the funeral address?
examples.ja: 誰が弔辞を読むのですか。

meaning_mnemonic: When someone <kanji>quit</kanji>s living you need to offer your <kanji>condolence</kanji>s during their <vocabulary>memorial address</vocabulary>. Let it all out and tell everyone what you thought about that dead guy.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meanings: To Hold A Memorial Service For

examples.en: We’re building a stone memorial for the souls of soldiers who died in battle.
examples.ja: ここには、殉職者の魂を弔う石碑が建てられています。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>condolence</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to mourn for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to condole</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You seem <vocabulary>to mourn for</vocabulary> things you really care about. Well then you would mourn for your <reading>toe mura</reading>l (とむら). You had a mural made for your favorite toe so if anything were to happen to it, you would want to mourn for it.

examples.en: First of all, it’s important to cut off the vicious cycle in your heart.
examples.ja: まずは、あなたの心の悪循環を断ち切ることが大切です。

meaning_mnemonic: You already know that 循環 means "circulation" or "cycle," so adding <kanji>bad</kanji> to that makes it a <vocabulary>vicious cycle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There are five circulatory organ specialists in this hospital.
examples.ja: 当院には、循環器専門医が五人います。

meaning_mnemonic: You already know that 循環 means "circulation," so adding <kanji>container</kanji> makes it what holds things that circulate. They're your <vocabulary>circulatory organ</vocabulary>s. They contain all the blood moving throughout your body like a container.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I lost a precious person.
examples.ja: 惜しい人を亡くしたものだ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>frugal</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>regrettable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>precious</vocabulary>. If you're too frugal to buy something your actions are regrettable later when you realize you wanted that thing. If you're so frugal you only buy one single thing, it's very precious to you.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You made a <vocabulary>regrettable</vocabulary> decision. You didn't buy that clock you wanted and now it's been discontinued. The salesperson tells you this and all you can say is, "<reading>Oh</reading>..." (お) really really quietly. How <vocabulary>disappointing</vocabulary>.

examples.en: I watched that video and it was unpleasant.
examples.ja: このビデオは、見ていて不愉快です。

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that 愉快 means "pleasant" or "happy," so add <kanji>not</kanji> to that and you're <vocabulary>unpleasant</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>unhappy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: She looked this way with a sorrowful expression on her face.
examples.ja: 彼女は、憂いを帯びた顔でこちらを見ていた。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, but wait! It's not an adjective, it's just a noun (tricky, tricky). The kanji means <kanji>grief</kanji>, so this word means <vocabulary>grief</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>distress</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 憂える. Remember that and you'll remember this!

examples.en: He boldly collected data from all over the world.
examples.ja: 彼は、世界各地で果敢な取材をしていた。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>daring</kanji> <kanji>fruit</kanji> is very <vocabulary>resolute</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>bold</vocabulary>! She's going to go out and be a fruit superhero or scientist or something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I only dared to say something so intense because it was to you.
examples.ja: あなただからこそ、敢えて厳しいことを言わせてもらったんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>daring</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>dare to</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>daringly</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're about to <vocabulary>daringly</vocabulary> jump off a cliff and you shout, "<reading>AAAHHH</reading> (あ)!" to get your courage up! You always have to yell AAHH before you dare to do daring things!

examples.en: Do you really intend to carry out this strategy?
examples.ja: 本当にこの作戦を敢行するつもりですか。

meaning_mnemonic: You use your <kanji>daring</kanji> and just <kanji>go</kanji>! You made a <vocabulary>decisive action</vocabulary> by just going like that! It was go or not go and you chose go!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That man plans to boldly oppose the difficult situation with nothing but his own determination.
examples.ja: あの男は、まるで自分の意志で敢然と難局に立ち向かっているつもりなのよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you have a <kanji>daring</kanji> <kanji>nature</kanji> you'll <vocabulary>boldly</vocabulary> go where no one else has gone before!

Note that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I think I fought pretty bravely against a favorite for the championship.
examples.ja: 優勝候補を相手に、よく敢闘したと思います。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you're involved in a <kanji>daring</kanji> <kanji>fight</kanji>, you're probably <vocabulary>fighting bravely</vocabulary>. You could get hurt, or worse, but you don't even care! Talk about fighting bravely… And good luck with that.

敢闘 is a very formal word often used to praise someone who gave it their all — especially in competitions — even if they didn't win. You might see it in phrases like 敢闘賞 (Fighting Spirit Award) at school sports festivals and sumo tournaments.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Your father was a very brave soldier.
examples.ja: お前の父さんは、とても勇敢な戦士だったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>courage</kanji> and <kanji>daring</kanji>! You're a <vocabulary>brave</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>heroic</vocabulary> hero of old. A samurai perhaps?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I practiced a figure eight turn in the garage.
examples.ja: ガレージで八の字旋回の練習をしてみました。

meaning_mnemonic: It doesn't matter how many <kanji>times</kanji> a <kanji>rotation</kanji> goes around, it's still a <vocabulary>rotation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The whirlwind changed to a storm right in front of the pirates.
examples.ja: 海賊達の目の前で、旋風は嵐へと変わっていった。

examples.en: In this country, an anime called "Galaxy Cyclone Braiger" has created a great sensation among young people.
examples.ja: この国では、『銀河旋風ブライガー』というアニメが若者達の間に大旋風を巻き起こしています。

examples.en: Tofugu is creating a whirlwind in the Japanese learning industry.
examples.ja: トーフグは、日本語学習業界に旋風を巻き起こしています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>rotation</kanji> of <kanji>wind</kanji> forms a <vocabulary>whirlwind</vocabulary>, in both the physical and figurative senses. On the figurative side, it can also mean <vocabulary>commotion</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>sensation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because ふう becomes ぷう here (hehe).

examples.en: I could always hear the melody of a beautiful piano from that house.
examples.ja: あの家からは、いつも美しいピアノの旋律が聞こえていました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you follow the <kanji>law</kanji> of <kanji>rotation</kanji> while you play music you'll end up with a lovely <vocabulary>melody</vocabulary>. If you don't, you'll miss all the cues on beat that rotation gives you and it will sound like crap.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The maple leaves started to change color too.
examples.ja: 楓の葉も色づいてきました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: I often use maple sugar instead of sugar in my cooking.
examples.ja: 料理には砂糖の代わりに楓糖を使うことが多いです。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Maple</kanji> <kanji>sugar</kanji> is <vocabulary>maple sugar</vocabulary>!

While you sometimes see 楓糖 on packaging for maple sugar or products made with it, in everyday life it's more common to just say メープルシュガー.
reading_mnemonic:
楓 uses the kun'yomi and 糖 uses the on'yomi. You already learned both of these, so you should have no problem with this word's reading: かえでとう. You might see some stores use this instead of メープルシュガー to keep things short and… maple-sweet.

楓糖 can also be read as ふうとう, using the on'yomi for both kanji. Since 楓 contains the 風 component, it makes sense that its on'yomi is ふう, right? Just know that ふうとう sounds a bit more technical or formal than something you'd sprinkle in your morning oatmeal.

examples.en: How often do you clean the fish tank?
examples.ja: どのくらい頻繁に水槽の掃除をしますか。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>tank</kanji> of <kanji>water</kanji> can be used as a <vocabulary>fish tank</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>water tank</vocabulary> for drinking. It really only depends on you and how many fish you have.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When I don’t clean it everyday, the bathtub accumulates grime.
examples.ja: 毎日掃除をしないと、浴槽には垢がたまります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>tank</kanji> you <kanji>bathe</kanji> in is a <vocabulary>bathtub</vocabulary>. Unless you're bathing in like... the town's water supply. If you are, please stop. I don't want to drink your bathwater.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Did you know that Japan offers international yen loans to many countries?
examples.ja: 日本が多くの国に円借款を提供しているのはご存知ですか。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>article</kanji> that proves that you're only <kanji>borrow</kanji>ing money or stuffed animals is called a <vocabulary>loan</vocabulary>. You have to pay that person back for those fluffy critters.

examples.en: Crows pick through garbage.

examples.en: Oolong tea without ice, please.
examples.ja: 烏龍茶を氷抜きでください。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Imperial</kanji> <kanji>tea</kanji> the color of a <kanji>crow</kanji>'s feathers can only be the famous, delicious <vocabulary>Oolong tea</vocabulary>. It came from the imperial people of China to Japan (probably) and there are lots of different variants. But the leaves are all that blackish/grey crow feather color.
reading_mnemonic:
This word takes the on'yomi readings except for 龍 which is an exception (sorry). You haven't learned the on'yomi for 烏 yet either, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who loves <vocabulary>Oolong tea</vocabulary> more than anyone else? <reading>Oooo Ron</reading> (うーろん) Weasley from Harry Potter. He's British, so of course you'd think he loves tea, but Oolong is his jam. Just picture him and think, oooooh it's Ron, when you drink this kind of tea.

And make sure you remember that, because this is also a written in katakana when the kanji isn't used, to type out the long mark ー when you enter your answer.

examples.en: A man lives in that house who was born blind.
examples.ja: その家には、生まれつき盲人の男が住んでいます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>blind</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>blind person</vocabulary>.

examples.en: That man covered all the tasks here in just one month.
examples.ja: あの男はたった一ヶ月で、ここでの業務を網羅した。

meaning_mnemonic:
If your <kanji>net</kanji> is <kanji>spread out</kanji> widely enough, it'll be <vocabulary>covering</vocabulary> everything. You're going to have to spread it out really, really far, though.

網羅 is a relatively formal word that means "covering" in the metaphorical sense, like an exhaustive list or a reference document <vocabulary>encompassing</vocabulary> all the information in a particular field. It gives off a strong feeling of "wow, they really got it all!" or even a proud "yep, I covered it all" kind of vibe.

examples.en: It looks like she refused an abortion.

meaning_mnemonic:
If you bring <kanji>degradation</kanji> to a <kanji>womb</kanji>, and there was a fetus in it, it causes an <vocabulary>abortion</vocabulary>. Or, in the case of an unwanted criminal abortion, <vocabulary>feticide</vocabulary>.

This word is very formal and is often used in legal contexts or literature.

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Membrane</kanji>s that wrap around at an <kanji>angle</kanji> are in your eye. Eyes are round and the membranes have to bend around the front part at an angle. It's called your <vocabulary>cornea</vocabulary>.

examples.en: The retina is a membrane inside your eye that resembles a camera’s film.

meaning_mnemonic: In the back of your eye there's a <kanji>net</kanji>-like <kanji>membrane</kanji> called the <vocabulary>retina</vocabulary>. It's net-like because it catches… light! You know, to help you see.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 芽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When a plant sprouts out of the ground it's still a baby so all it can say is goo goo <reading>ga</reading> ga (が).

examples.en: I'm thinking about making stewed cuttlefish this evening.

meaning_mnemonic: Look in the sea and you'll see what looks like a <kanji>crow</kanji> moving under the water and it's a <kanji>thief</kanji>! It's stealing from all the fish. As it comes closer you see that it isn't a crow, it's a <vocabulary>squid</vocabulary>. Or a <vocabulary>cuttlefish</vocabulary>? One or the other.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this word is completely irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

You call the fish police to arrest that thieving <vocabulary>squid</vocabulary>, but it jumps into it's <reading>ea</reading>gle <reading>ca</reading>r (いか) and makes a swift getaway. In case you didn't know, an eagle car is an eagle moonlighting as a car. The eagle car is zooming up into the sky, so there's no way the fish police can catch it now.

examples.en: During the voyage they were attacked by pirates.
examples.ja: 航海の途中で海賊に襲われました。

examples.en: No matter how many times I see this movie, I always cry.

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>What</kanji>'s <kanji>universal</kanji>? <vocabulary>How many times</vocabulary> do you think that question's been asked throughout time? Probably a lot of times.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word with an unusual reading, where the first kanji uses kun'yomi and the second uses on'yomi. You've seen these readings before, so you should be able to read this. Just watch out, because へん becomes べん here!

examples.en: Michael has a unique romantic history.
examples.ja: マイケルにはおもしろい恋愛遍歴がある。

examples.en: Don’t you think a woman who talks about her history with men is super annoying?
examples.ja: 過去の男性遍歴を語ってくる女ってマジでうざいよな。

examples.en: That masterless samurai has decided to travel around various countries.
examples.ja: その浪人は、諸国を遍歴することにした。

meaning_mnemonic:
It’s a <kanji>universal</kanji> truth that we are the <kanji>continuation</kanji> of our <vocabulary>experiences</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>history</vocabulary>.

The original meaning of this word is <vocabulary>journey</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>travels</vocabulary>, in the literal sense of the word, but nowadays you’d usually use it more abstractly, to talk about things like your past experiences, or perhaps your spiritual journey.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It’s rude to interrupt a person.
examples.ja: 人の話を遮るのは失礼です。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>intercept</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to intercept</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to interrupt</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The thing you want <vocabulary>to interrupt</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to intercept</vocabulary> is your roommate's <reading>sighing gui</reading>tar (さえぎ). He keeps playing it and all it does is make these horrible, long sighing sounds. You want to interrupt it any cost.

examples.en: Access to the site has been cut off.
examples.ja: サイトへのアクセスが遮断されました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>intercept</kanji> trade and <kanji>cut off</kanji> a country from the rest of the world they'll be stuck in a state of <vocabulary>isolation</vocabulary> or if they have some kind of disease like zombie-itus, it's a <vocabulary>quarantine</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Enzyme diets are popular among young women right now.

meaning_mnemonic: The one <kanji>element</kanji> you need to <kanji>ferment</kanji> something is an <vocabulary>enzyme</vocabulary>. That breaks whatever you're trying to ferment down in just the right way.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m using my own yeast to make bread.
examples.ja: 自作酵母を使ってパンを作っています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>mother</kanji> of good <kanji>ferment</kanji>ation is <vocabulary>yeast</vocabulary>! If you want to bake a pie or bread you have to have the best. And if you don't have any, maybe your neighbor has some extra that you can borrow?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please teach me how to keep the sweetness in wine and stop fermentation.
examples.ja: ワインの甘みを残して発酵を止める方法を教えてください。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>ferment</kanji> something it makes a <kanji>departure</kanji> from what it originally was and transforms during <vocabulary>fermentation</vocabulary> into something new.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: They brew sake here.
examples.ja: ここで酒を醸成しているんですね。

meaning_mnemonic: Beer can only <kanji>become</kanji> <kanji>brew</kanji>ed if you decide to <vocabulary>brew</vocabulary> it. Beer can't make itself, you know.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I toured the scotch distillery.
examples.ja: スコッチの醸造所を見学してきました。

examples.en: The idol’s bold statement is giving rise to public criticism.

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>brew</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to brew</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to distill</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You want <vocabulary>to brew</vocabulary> up some beer but not the regular boring stuff. You're going to make it from the water in the hump of a <reading>camel</reading> (かも). Camel beer is definitely not a horrible idea, right?

examples.en: For the time being, let’s wait until dad’s anger has calmed down.
examples.ja: とりあえず、今は父の怒りが鎮まるのを待ちましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that 鎮める means "to appease," but this one is what happens after they've been appeased. They start <vocabulary>to quiet down</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you're in the library the librarian is always telling you <vocabulary>to quiet down</vocabulary>. <reading>She's</reading> (しず) so mean! She never lets you talk in the library. Who's mean to you? She's mean to you!!

examples.en: There are browsing restrictions on this website.
examples.ja: このウェブサイトには閲覧規制がかかっています。

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <kanji>look at</kanji> and give a quick <kanji>inspection</kanji> of some stuff then you're just <vocabulary>browsing</vocabulary>. You don't want to buy yet, you just have to give a look.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Internet censorship is practiced in this country.

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>examine</kanji> something too closely during your <kanji>inspection</kanji> you'll probably find a flaw and want to <vocabulary>censor</vocabulary> it. Put little black bars over all the flaws you find as you stare.

examples.en: Could you revise my manuscript for me?
examples.ja: 原稿を校閲してもらえませんか。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>inspection</kanji> you make of your homework before <kanji>school</kanji> is a <vocabulary>revision</vocabulary>. Sometimes <vocabulary>proofreading</vocabulary> will help you find mistakes before you hand it in too. Just make sure you look everything over.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That coach is good at encouraging player morale.

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>beat</kanji> makes you want to <kanji>dance</kanji>. It's the <vocabulary>inspiration</vocabulary> you need to dance. The beat gives you <vocabulary>encouragement</vocabulary> to dance all night long. And without such a rockin' beat you would have lame dance moves.

examples.ja: 彼女は、袋の中に鼓を大切そうにしまった。

examples.en: I've never seen such a cute tsuzumi. Did you make it, by any chance?
examples.ja: そんな可愛い鼓、見たことないよ。もしかして、手作り？

meaning_mnemonic: What do you hit to make a sick <kanji>beat</kanji>? A cool little <vocabulary>hand drum</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You like to use your <vocabulary>hand drum</vocabulary> when <reading>two du</reading>des <reading>mee</reading>t (つづみ). You drum and tap it as they high five and it makes them super uncomfortable which makes you super happy. That's why you love your hand drum so much.

examples.en: The young girl’s face turned red and her heart throbbed.
examples.ja: 少女の顔が赤くなり、鼓動が高鳴りました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>beat</kanji> that <kanji>move</kanji>s inside your body is the <vocabulary>beat</vocabulary>ing of your heart. Put your hand up to your neck and you should be able to feel it <vocabulary>pulse</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If you play things that loudly you’ll tear your eardrums.
examples.ja: そんなに大声を出されたら鼓膜が破れるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You can hear something <kanji>beat</kanji> because of a <kanji>membrane</kanji> in your ear called an <vocabulary>eardrum</vocabulary>. Make sure you don't stick your fingers too far in your ear or you could really hurt it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My children like to play with drums.
examples.ja: うちの子供は太鼓で遊ぶのが好きです。

examples.en: My stomach is so full that it looks like a drum.
examples.ja: お腹がパンパンで太鼓みたいになっています。

examples.en: I'm really into a game called "Taiko Master."
examples.ja: 「太鼓の達人」っていうゲームにハマってるんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>fat</kanji> <kanji>drum</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>drum</vocabulary>. This word can be used for any type of drum, but a common one in Japan is the <vocabulary>taiko</vocabulary>. There are lots of different types of taiko, and most of them are big and fat, and make a lovely deep sound. They're super cool to watch and play!

If talking about taiko drums specifically, you can also say 和太鼓 to be clear that you're not talking about any old drums.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: To cure my fatigue and recover quickly, I drank green tea and ate mochi for a week.
examples.ja: 疲れを癒して、早く回復するために、一週間緑茶を飲んだりお餅を食べたりしました。

examples.en: I was healed by Riko-chan's kind smile.
examples.ja: 莉子ちゃんの優しい笑顔に癒された。

examples.en: Ryoichiro quenched his thirst for knowledge through reading.
examples.ja: 諒一郎は読書によって知識への渇きを癒すことができた。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>healing</kanji> and the verb version means <vocabulary>to heal something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to cure something</vocabulary>, and even <vocabulary>to quench a thirst</vocabulary>, both literally and metaphorically. As you can probably guess, this last use has a poetic feel to it.

Like many verbs ending in す, this verb is transitive, meaning it's being done to something. So you can use it when you cure an illness, heal a broken heart, or quench your thirst for adventure!
reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>To heal something</vocabulary> it's sometimes necessary to do something <reading>いや</reading> (gross). Even if you dislike it, even if it's gross, you do it anyway, because you want to heal whatever it is.

examples.en: Ryota's face turned pale with anger.
examples.ja: 遼太は怒りで顔面蒼白になった。

examples.en: The patient's face was pallid and he looked extremely weak.
examples.ja: 患者は蒼白な顔をしていて、非常に弱々しく見えました。

examples.en: The General, who had been awake all night, sat down to breakfast, looking as pale as a ghost.
examples.ja: 一晩中起きていた元帥は、まるで幽霊のように蒼白な顔をして朝食の席についた。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>pale</kanji> <kanji>white</kanji>, you're <vocabulary>pale</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>pallid</vocabulary>. This word is usually used to talk about the <vocabulary>pallor</vocabulary> of someone's face.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You learned those readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Takuya-san is an admirable man.
examples.ja: 拓哉さんは殊勝な男性です。

examples.en: Takuya and Eito shared a hug under the crimson sky.
examples.ja: 茜色の空の下で拓哉と瑛斗は抱擁を交わしました。

examples.en: The celebrity Kimura Takuya is so famous in Japan that everyone calls him by his nickname, Kimutaku.
examples.ja: タレントの木村拓哉は、日本ではとても有名で、キムタクという愛称で親しまれています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>cultivation</kanji> of a <kanji>question mark</kanji> is something that only people called <vocabulary>Takuya</vocabulary> can do. Imagine a famous Takuya, like actor and singer Kimura Takuya (木村 拓哉 a.k.a. キムタク), or a Takuya you know, cultivating a huge field of question marks. Rows and rows of question marks. I wonder what he's going to do with all those question marks once they're ready to harvest. Other people who must have an abundance of question marks are pro baseball player Kinoshita Takuya (木下 拓哉 a.k.a. キノタク) and actor, model, and K-Pop star Terada Takuya (寺田 拓哉).
reading_mnemonic: You learned both of these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this name on your own.
